Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Multiscale Dynamics of the Tropical Upper Troposphere and Lower Stratosphere
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project to support a junior faculty member in developing and conducting an integrated 5-year program of research and education in atmospheric science. The research component is a study of the mechanisms which govern the temperature structure of the Tropical Tropopause Layer (TTL), the layer of the upper troposphere and lower stratosphere between about 200mb (roughly the level of tropical convective outflow) and 70mb. The TTL is scientifically interesting because it contains the interface between the troposphere and stratosphere, including the cold point tropopause (around 100mb), and conditions in the TTL control the entry of atmospheric tracers into the stratosphere, including water vapor. Water vapor is of particular interest due to its strong radiative effects, and because of the role of stratospheric clouds in the formation of the ozone hole. The amount of water vapor entering the stratosphere in turn depends strongly on temperature in the TTL, and temperature is determined by a variety of mechanisms from individual convective plumes to planetary-scale circulations. This project explores the full range of mechanisms using a hierarchy of numerical models, including single-column radiative-convective model, a cloud resolving model with a pan-tropical domain, and a comprehensive chemistry-climate model. The project will attempt to understand why temperature continues to decrease with height between the convective cloud tops and the cold point tropopause, and the processes which drive temperature variability within the TTL.

The educational component of the project seeks to introduce students and the general public to atmospheric science through "tales of great discoveries". The goal of the activity is to teach science from a historical perspective, emphasizing science as a human and social endeavor that occurs within a particular historical context. This approach has been used to teach physics to general audiences, and studies show that the historical approach can make physics more approachable for non-specialists. But despite the success of this approach for physics it has not been developed previously atmospheric science. Through this award the PI will work with the outreach program at the Center for Multiscale Modeling of Atmospheric Processes (CMMAP) to present several tales of discovery, including the discovery of the tropopause and stratosphere, the discovery of the Brewer-Dobson circulation, the discovery of the Quasi-Biennial Oscillation, and the discovery of the ozone hole.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we studied processes that control the temperature structure and its variability near the tropical tropopause. The tropical tropopause represents the gateway to the stratosphere within the upward branch of the hemispheric-scale mass circulation of the stratosphere. Tropical tropopause temperatures control the amount of water vapor that enters the stratosphere, which in turn affects the stratospheric radiative budget — an important control on stratospheric climate with potential consequences down to the surface. Unfortunately, controls on tropical tropopause temperatures are still not well understood and climate models show large spread in simulated temperatures in this region. Hence there remain large uncertainties in stratospheric water abundances which translate into uncertainties for future predictions of stratospheric climate.

The planetary-scale upwelling through the tropical tropopause directly causes adiabatic cooling, but also transports radiatively active tracers, most importantly water vapor and ozone. The altered vertical profiles of these radiative tracers in turn modify tropical tropopause temperatures, giving rise to an indirect temperature control by the upwelling. Our results have clarified both direct and indirect roles of this upwelling. In particular, we have quantified the crucial role of ozone radiative effects in creating a realistic tropical tropopause layer in the first place, and our results have underlined the importance of simulating a realistic ozone profile for a realistic representation of tropical tropopause temperatures in current climate models.

Our research work has further substantiated the indirect convective control on tropical tropopause temperatures via hydrostatic large-scale (order of 1000 km) tropopause-level cooling aloft convective heating. And our analyses of water vapor transport through the tropical tropopause have indicated a first-order importance of vertical mixing/dispersion on top of the planetary-scale upwelling. Such vertical dispersion is only poorly represented in current climate models. To what extent it manifests itself as means of transport of first-order importance remains to be clarified in future research.

Overall, this project has improved our basic understanding of the temperature structure and associated variability near the tropical tropopause and hence provides guidance as to how to improve future climate model simulations. It has also exemplified multiscale interactions in the climate system — an area of increasing importance because 1) as the spatial resolution of models improves, more of the relevant processes are resolved, allowing such interaction, 2) interactions between subgrid scale (parametrized) and resolved processes constitutes a challenge for realistic climate simulations.

This project also involved a substantial educational component. Supported by this grant, the PI has developed an educational outreach program based on tales of great discovery, focusing on the discovery of the stratosphere around the turn of the 20th century (motivated by overall research topic of grant). This way, not only the existing body of knowledge is taught, but also how science is being done (the nature of science). This outreach program has been delivered multiple times (~20 times in total over course of project) to a wide range of audiences, focusing on middle and high school children and teachers. In several instances it involved class visits to the Department of Atmospheric Science at Colorado State University by middle or high school classes, where a weather balloon was launched and the resulting temperature data was used to rediscover the stratosphere. The outreach program was continuously evaluated by education research specialists at CSU; an education research study on discourse dynamics in science outreach (MS thesis supported by this project) was conducted.
